DOC.HEAD: Joel Jacobson, Former Casino Control Commissioner, Dies
DOC.TEXT: Joel Jacobson, a no-nonsense former New Jersey casino regulator who once called Frank Sinatra ``an obnoxious bully'' and was later appointed court trustee of a scandal-ridden Teamsters local, died Tuesday. He was 71. Jacobson, a South Orange resident, died about 3:25 a.m. at Saint Barnabas Hospital in Livingston, said a hospital spokeswoman who asked that her name not be used. She said she could not release a cause of death. ``I am saddened at the death of Joel Jacobson,'' Gov. Thomas H. Kean said in a statement. ``He was an individual of strong and firmly held positions and possessed a willingness to express them forcefully and articulately. He fought for his beliefs, both as a public servant and as a private citizen.'' Jacobson, a longtime labor union official, joined the state Casino Control commission in 1981. His tenure was marked by his vote against issuing a gaming license to Hilton Corp. and his run-in with Sinatra. In 1984, he characterized the singer as someone who ``walks into a casino and exhibits himself like an obnoxious bully, forcing men and women to commit infractions because of the fear of losing their jobs.'' The comment came after Sinatra and fellow entertainer Dean Martin forced a blackjack dealer at the former Golden Nugget casino to deal from her hand instead of a plastic ``shoe'' which holds the cards. Jacobson's remark so angered Sinatra that he refused to perform in the state for a time. Outgoing Casino Control Commission Chairman Walter N. Read said Jacobson never feared letting others know what he thought. ``Joel had a lot of influence in a lot of areas for a long period of time,'' Read said. Jacobson resigned from the commission in June 1986 and was appointed by U.S. District Judge Harold Ackerman to run Union City-based Teamsters Local 560. Ackerman had ruled in February 1984 that the 8,000-member Local 560 had suffered under ``an orgy of criminal activity'' for 25 years. In May 1987, Ackerman removed Jacobson, saying ``more needs to be done in order to insure that the documented egregious pattern of racketeering activity does not re-emerge the moment that the trusteeship is ended.'' Jacobson later accused the government of trying to bust the union with the appointment of Edwin H. Stier, a former assistant U.S. attorney and director of the state Division of Criminal Justice. The union in 1988 held a government monitored election and returned to self-administration. In 1974, Jacobson became a member of the state Board of Public Utilities and its president in 1976. He became the first commissioner of the state Department of Energy _ now part of the state Department of Commerce, Energy and Economic Development _ upon its creation in 1977.
